sen.j: 平 敦盛（たいら の あつもり）は、平安時代末期の武将。
sen.e: TAIRA no Atsumori was a Japanese military commander lived during the late Heian Period.
TAIRA no Atsumori was a Japanese military commander lived during the late Heian Period.

sen.j: 平清盛の弟である平経盛の末子。
sen.e: He was born the youngest son to TAIRA no Tsunemori, a younger brother of TAIRA no Kiyomori.
He was born as the youngest son of TAIRA no Tsunemori, a younger brother of TAIRA no Kiyomori.
sen.cmt: bornの後にasを入れto→ofにしました。
sen.e: He was born as the youngest son of TAIRA no Tsunemori, a younger brother of TAIRA no Kiyomori.

sen.j: 位階は従五位。
sen.e: Atsumori had a rank of Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank).
Atsumori had a rank of Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank).

sen.j: 官職にはついておらず、無官大夫と称された。
sen.e: As he did not hold any post, he was called Mukan no Taifu (No-post master).

sen.j: 笛の名手であり、祖父平忠盛が鳥羽天皇より賜った『小枝』（または『青葉』）という笛を譲り受ける。
sen.e: Atsumori was a well-known flute master and handed down a flute called "Saeda" (a twig) or "Aoba" (a type of bamboo) from his grandfather, TAIRA no Tadamori, who received the flute from Emperor Toba.

sen.j: 伊勢平氏として17歳で一ノ谷の戦いに参加。
sen.e: Atsumori joined the Battle of Ichinotani as the Ise-Heishi clan at the age of 17.

sen.j: 源氏側の奇襲を受け、平氏側が劣勢になると、敦盛は騎馬で海上の船に逃げようとした。
sen.e: When the Taira clan was pushed into an inferior position by an ambush by the Minamoto clan, Atsumori who was riding a horse tried to escape to a ship.

sen.j: すると、敵将を探していた熊谷直実が「敵に後ろを見せるのは卑怯でありましょう、お戻りなされ」と呼び止める。
sen.e: Then, Naozane KUMAGAI, who was looking for an enemy general, stopped Atsumori and said, 'only a coward shows his back to his enemy. You should come back'.

sen.j: 敦盛が取って返すと、直実は敦盛を馬から組み落とし、首を斬ろうと甲を上げる。
sen.e: As soon as Atsumori retraced his steps, Naozane wrestled Atsumori down the horse and thrust his hand into the air to kill the man.

sen.j: すると、我が子熊谷直家と同じ年頃の美しい若者の顔を見て躊躇する。
sen.e: However, Naoie hesitated when looking at the face of a beautiful young man who seemed almost the same age of his son, Naoie KUMAGAI.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.cmt: Howeverの直後のNaoieはNaozaneの誤りと思われましたので訂正しました。
sen.e: However, Naozane hesitated when looking at the face of a beautiful young man who seemed almost the same age of his son, Naoie KUMAGAI.

sen.j: 直実は敦盛を助けようと名を尋ねるが、敦盛は「お前のためには良い敵だ、名乗らずとも首を取って人に尋ねよ。すみやかに首を取れ」と答え、直実は涙ながらに敦盛の首を切った。
sen.e: Naozane asked Atsumori's name to let him go, but Atsumori only replied, 'I am a good enemy for your career. You should kill me before knowing my name and ask someone later. Kill me immediately', and Naozane beheaded Atsumori in tears.

Naozane asked Atsumori's name to save his life, but Atsumori only replied, 'I am a good enemy for your career. You should kill me before knowing my name and ask someone later. Kill me immediately', and Naozane, in tears, beheaded Atsumori.
sen.cmt: to let him go→to save his lifeにしました。この場合の｢良い敵」は｢(手柄を上げるのに)格好な犠牲」という意味で、「good enemy」とは違う気がするのですが、適当な表現が見つかりませんでした。（杞憂かもしれませんが）in tearsがこの位置ですと、敦盛が涙を流しているように解釈されかねませんので、Naozaneの直後に移動しました。
sen.e: Naozane asked Atsumori's name to save his life, but Atsumori only replied, 'I am a perfect enemy to kill for you to achieve a feat. You should kill me before knowing my name and ask someone later. Kill me immediately', and Naozane, in tears, beheaded Atsumori.

sen.j: この事から、直実の出家の志が一段と強くなったという発心譚が語られる。
sen.e: It is said that this incident made Naozane inclined toward the priesthood even more.
It is said that this incident made Naozane inclined toward the priesthood even more.

sen.j: 「延慶本」や「鎌倉本」では、直実が敦盛の笛（または篳篥）を屋島にいる敦盛の父平経盛の元に送り、直実の書状と経盛の返状が交わされる場面が描かれている。
sen.e: In the 'Enkyo bon' and 'Kamakura bon' (both are different versions of Heike Monogatari [The tale of the Heike]), there is a scene where Naozane is sending the flute of Atsumori to his father, TAIRA no Tsunemori, who lived in Yashima Island, and where letters from Naozane to Tsunemori and vice versa are also exchanged.

sen.j: 淡路島煙島に敦盛の史跡がある。
sen.e: Historic sites of Atsumori can be found in Kemuri-jima, Awaji-shima Island.

sen.j: この『平家物語』の名場面は、のちに能『敦盛 (能)』、幸若舞『敦盛 (幸若舞)』、謡曲『敦盛 (謡曲)』、歌舞伎『一谷嫩軍記』などの題材となった。
sen.e: This famous scene from "Heike Monogatari" was also used as a subject in plays and songs titled "Atsumori" of Noh (traditional masked dance-drama), Kowaka-mai (story-telling with a simple dance) and Yokyoku (Noh song), and also in the Kabuki play titled " Ichi no Tani Futabagunki" (Chronicle of the Battle of Ichinotani).

sen.j: 織田信長の好んだ下記の歌は幸若舞の『敦盛 (幸若舞)』の一節である。
sen.e: The following poem famous for having been favored by Nobunaga ODA is from "Atsumori" of Kowaka-mai.

sen.j: 『人間五十年、下天のうちをくらぶれば、夢幻の如くなり。一度生を享け滅せぬもののあるべきか』
sen.e: "To think that a man has but fifty years to live under Heaven… Surely this world is nothing but a vain dream. Living but one life, is there anything that will not decay?"

sen.j: 広島県庄原市には古くから「敦盛さん」という民謡（市の無形民俗文化財）が伝わっている。
sen.e: In Shobara City, Hiroshima Prefecture, one minyo (a traditional folk song) titled 'Atsumori-san' has sung since ancient times (the song was designated as an intangible folk cultural property of the city).

sen.j: それによると敦盛の室（玉織姫、庄原では「姫御さん」と呼ばれる）が、敦盛は生きているとの言い伝えを頼りに各地を巡り歩き、庄原に至ってそこに住んだ、という。
sen.e: According to the song, the lawful wife of Atsumori, Tamaori-hime (also called as 'Himego-san' in Shobara), traveled around the country to find Atsumori by trusting a rumor that Atsumori was still alive, and finally settled down in Shobara.

According to the song, the lawful wife of Atsumori, Tamaori-hime (also called as 'Himego-san' in Shobara), traveled various places to find Atsumori relying on rumors that Atsumori was still alive, and finally settled down in Shobara.
sen.cmt: around the country→various places、by trusting→relying onとしました。

sen.j: 庄原市春田にはその玉織姫の墓といわれるものが残っている。
sen.e: In Shunda Town, Shobara City, there still remains what is believed to be a tomb of Tamaori-hime.
In Shunda Town, Shobara City, there still remains what has been believed to be a tomb of Tamaori-hime.

sen.j: どのような経緯で伝承が生まれたのかは定かではなく、全国各地に見られる平家の落人伝説の一種と見られる。
sen.e: It is not known exactly how this legend was generated, but it is regarded as one of the legends of Heike no Ochiudo (fleeing Heike warrior) passed down for generations in various parts of Japan.

sen.j: しかし敦盛を討ったとされる熊谷直実は安芸国に所領を与えられており、また熊谷氏は戦国時代 (日本)に至るまで安芸に土着していることから、その点と何らかの関係がある可能性も考えられる。
sen.e: However, considering that Naozane KUMAGAI, who is believed to have killed Atsumori, was given Aki Province and lived in the province throughout the Sengoku Period, Naozane may have something to do with the legend.

However, considering that Naozane KUMAGAI, who has been supposed to have killed Atsumori, was given a territory in Aki Province and lived in the province by the Sengoku Period, Naozane may have some relationships with the legend.
sen.cmt: is believed→has been supposedとしました。givenとAki Provinceの間に、「所領」を意味するa territoryを挿入しました。「(戦国時代に)至るまで」なので、throughout→byにしました。Have something to do→have some relationshipsとしました。
sen.e: However, considering that Naozane KUMAGAI, who has been supposed to have killed Atsumori, was given a territory in Aki Province and lived in the province by the Sengoku Period, Naozane may have some relationships with the legend.

sen.j: 直実は建久元年（1190年）法然の勧めにより、高野山で敦盛の七回忌法要を行っている。
sen.e: Naozane held a Buddhist memorial service to commemorate the sixth anniversary of Atsumori's death in Mt. Koya-san in 1190, as proposed by Honen.

sen.j: またでは、実は敦盛は後白河院のご落胤で、直実はそれを知っていて、自分の息子小次郎の首を刎ねたという記述となっている。
sen.e: In the Kabuki play of 'Ichinotani Futaba Gunki Kumagaya Jinya no ba', Atsumori is portrayed as an illegitimate child of the retired Emperor Goshirakawa, and Naozane, who knew it, beheaded his own son, Kojiro, instead.
